content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

Given my preference for security and predictability, I would choose to play this game strategically by choosing 'B' most of the time. The reason is that if my anonymous partner also chooses 'B', we both earn 20$ each round, which totals to 1500$ over 75 rounds. This is a guaranteed income and minimizes the risk of getting nothing (0$) when we choose differently.

If my partner chooses 'R' while I pick 'B', I still get 40$, which is not bad considering the worst-case scenario (if we both chose 'R') would earn me nothing. This means that even if my partner doesn't follow the same strategy, I can still benefit somewhat from choosing 'B'.

On the other hand, if I choose 'R' when my partner chooses 'B', I get 0$. However, considering there are only a limited number of rounds (75), and given that my partner might also be cautious like me and lean towards choosing 'B' more often, it is likely that we would have less than 38 instances where we both choose 'R'. This means that the probability of losing money by choosing 'R' is relatively small.

In summary, I would choose 'B' most of the time (75 - number_of_rounds_I_choose_R) to minimize the risk of getting nothing and maximize the guaranteed income, while also taking into account that my partner might follow a similar strategy.

{B}
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 20$. Your opponent's payoff is 20$. Please play the next round.

In this case, since both of us chose 'B' in the previous round and we received a payoff of 20$, I will continue to choose 'B' in the next round as well. By consistently choosing 'B', I aim to maximize my guaranteed income while minimizing the risk of losing money. If my opponent chooses differently this time, I will still get 20$ for that round, and we can then adjust our strategies based on our respective payoffs.

{B}
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

In this case, since my opponent chose 'R' and I chose 'B', I got a payoff of 40$, while my opponent received nothing. If we continue playing with the same strategies, I will likely earn more money than the guaranteed income (20$) by choosing 'B'. However, I am still cautious and prefer to maintain some degree of predictability in my choices.

At this point, since I have already seen that my opponent chooses 'R' once, it is possible that they might switch strategies and choose 'B' in the future to avoid losing money consistently. To maximize my earnings while maintaining a degree of security, I would wait for more evidence before considering a change in strategy.

For now, given my preference for predictability, I will continue choosing 'B'. If my opponent continues to choose 'R', I will evaluate whether it is worth switching strategies in the future to maximize my earnings.
